questions.question: Which of the following parameters is not indicative of reference Indian adult woman?
The energy required by an adult for basal metabolism is:
questions.explanation: The energy required by an adult for basal metabolism is 1 kcal/ hour/ kg of body weight.479

questions.question: What is the likely energy requirement of a pregnant woman who leads a moderately activelifestyle?
questions.explanation: The energy requirement of a pregnant woman who leads a moderately active lifestyle isaround 2500 kcal/day.An adult woman leading a moderately active lifestyle requires 2130 kcal daily and an additional350 kcal is needed in pregnancy. Hence, the total requirement for a moderately working pregnantwoman is 2480 kcal/ day (approximately 2500 kcal/ day).

questions.question: A nutritionist is preparing a meal plan for a healthy 32-year-old man. Which of the followingprinciples must she follow?

options.A: Proteins must constitute 15-30% of the daily energy intake
options.B: Fats must constitute 10-15% of the daily energy intake475
options.C: Carbohydrate requirement must be met first followed by protein and fat
options.D: The proportion of nutrients in the diet must be carbohydrates > fats > proteins

questions.explanation: The proportion of nutrients in the diet must be carbohydrates > fats > proteins.While constructing a balanced diet, nutrient requirements must be calculated in the followingsequence:• Protein requirements 10-15% of daily energy intake-• Fat requirement - 15-30% of daily energy intake•Carbohydrates - remaining food energy

questions.question: What is the daily requirement of high-quality protein for a 40-year-old man weighing 60 kgs?
questions.explanation: This man requires 50 g/day of high-quality protein.High-quality protein refers to proteins containing all the essential amino acids. According tothe FAO/WHO 2007 guidelines, the recommended high-quality protein intake for adult men andwomen is 0.83 g/kg/day. This man weighs 60 kgs. Hence he requires around 50 g (0.83*60 = 49.8)of high-quality protein per day.Recommended high-quality protein intake by FAO/WHO:However, the mixed Indian diet does not meet the requirement for high-quality protein. Hence,the protein requirement in Indian adults (men and women) is 1g/kg/day of mixed Indian dietprotein according to the ICMR 2010 guidelines.AgeProtein in g/kg/day1-5 years0.946-10 years0.91Adolescent male0.88Adolescent fem0.86ale480AgeProtein in g/kg/dayAdult man/wom0.83an

questions.question: A dietary protein-energy percentage of which of the following is the threshold for inadequate protein intake?
questions.explanation: Dietary protein-energy percentage (PE %) < 4% indicates inadequate protein intake. The PE % indicates the proportion of total energy in the diet that is derived from proteins. PE % = (Energy from protein / Total energy in the diet) * 100. Some of the food items and their protein-energy percentage are given below: Food PE% - Fish 80, Cow milk 20, Dal 24, Rice 8, Potato 60, Banana 4, Tapioca 2.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best indicator of protein quality?

options.A: Protein digestibility corrected amino acid score

questions.explanation: Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator for protein quality.DIAAS reflects the digestibility of individual amino acids in the protein. Total protein digestibilitydoes not always reflect the digestibility of individual dietary indispensable amino acids. Hence,DIAAS has replaced the PDCAAS (protein digestibility corrected amino acid score) as thepreferred index for the evaluation of protein quality.

questions.question: Which of the following has the highest net protein utilization value?
questions.explanation: Among the given options, meat has the highest net protein utilization (NPU).The NPU values of various food items in descending order are:481•Egg - 100• Meat - 80•• Milk - 75• Rice - 65•Soya - 61Low NPU indicates a high protein requirement. The NPU of Indian diets is usually between 50and 80.

questions.question: A farmer has been consuming a maize-rich diet for many years. Which of the following wouldbe lacking in his diet?
questions.explanation: His diet would be lacking lysine and tryptophan as maize is deficient in these amino acids.Principal FoodCereals (in general)Amino acid DeficientLysineMaizeLysine and TryptophanWheatLysine and ThreoninePulses (Poor man's meaMethionine and cysteit)ne

questions.question: Which of the following has the highest content of essential fatty acids?
questions.explanation: Safflower oil contains the highest content of essential fatty acids.Linoleic acid is the most important essential fatty acid.Milk is also rich in linoleic acid and oleic acid.Dietary sour % content of linoleic acidce

questions.question: You are counseling a diabetic patient to consume foods with low glycemic index. Which of thefollowing would you advise him to eat?
questions.explanation: Safflower oilCorn oil7550Sunflower oi621Soybean oil53482The patient should be advised to eat whole grains since it has a low glycemic index (GI).GI is a number representing the relative ability of a carbohydrate food to increase the level ofglucose in the blood. It is calculated by comparing the test carbohydrate to the standard (glucoseor white bread). This measure has practical use in the management of diabetes and obesity.-• Low GI foods – most fruits and vegetables, whole grains, pasta foods, beans, and lentils.•Moderate GI foods - sucrose, basmati rice, and brown rice.• High GI foods - corn flakes, baked potatoes, white bread, potatoes, watermelon, candies, andsyrupy foods.

questions.question: The renal feed of a patient suffering from end-stage renal disease (stage 5) should ideally be:
questions.explanation: The renal feed of a patient suffering from end-stage renal disease should ideally be low volume,high calories.Dietary factors may have an effect on the progression of kidney disease and its complications. Alow-volume feed is preferred in order to avoid:• Sodium and volume overload• Hyperkalemia• Hyperphosphatemia• Accumulation of toxic metabolites of protein degradationA high-calorie feed is preferred in order to combat the patient's risk of malnutrition and wastingseen in ESRD.

questions.question: Which of the following is not used in the assessment of body fat?
questions.explanation: Breslow's staging is used for the staging of malignant melanoma, not for the assessment of bodyfat.

questions.question: In the Indian population, individuals with BMI falling between which range are defined asoverweight?
questions.explanation: In the Indian (Asian) population, a BMI of 23-24.99 is classified as overweight.However, in the global population, a BMI of 25-29.99 is considered overweight.

questions.question: What value of BMI is considered as 'lethal' in men?
questions.explanation: A body mass index (BMI) of 13 or less is considered lethal in men.However, females can survive even at a lower BMI up to 11.483

questions.question: Which of the following indicators are used in Waterlow's classification?
questions.explanation: Waterlow's classification makes use of height for age (HFA) and weight for height (WFH) to assessthe nutritional status of children.HFA indicates stunting and denotes the chronicity of malnutrition. On the other hand,WFH indicates wasting and denotes the severity of malnutrition.The Gomez classification uses weight for age as an indicator of nutritional status. Thedisadvantage is that it is difficult to determine whether the low weight is due to an acute attack ofmalnutrition or chronic undernutrition.484
